MEANING: A high-level programming language known for its simplicity and readability.
Programs and applications that run on computers or other devices.
The process of creating or improving software products.
Instructions written in a programming language to perform a specific task or function.
The act of writing and designing computer programs.
A system of communication used to express instructions to a computer.
An electronic device capable of processing data according to programmed instructions.
A collection of elements or components working together to perform a task or function.
A software program designed to perform a specific task or set of tasks for the user.
A pre-built structure or platform that provides a foundation for developing software applications.
A collection of pre-written code or functions that can be reused in software development.
A self-contained unit of code that can be used and reused in various programs.
A named block of code that performs a specific task or operation.
A named storage location in computer memory used to hold data.
An instance of a class in object-oriented programming, encapsulating data and behavior.
A blueprint for creating objects, providing initial values and methods.
A function associated with a class, typically acting on its instances.
A unit of code that expresses some action to be carried out.
The rules that define the structure of a programming language.
A step-by-step procedure for solving a problem or accomplishing a task.
The process of finding and fixing errors or bugs in software code.
The process of evaluating a software application or system to find defects and ensure its quality.
Written information describing the functionality and use of software or hardware.
A specific iteration or release of a software product.
A storage location where software code and related assets are stored and managed.
Combining changes from different branches of code into a single codebase.
A record of changes made to a repository, typically accompanied by a message describing the changes.
A separate line of development in a version control system, allowing for parallel work on code.
Creating a copy of a repository or branch.
Fetching and integrating changes from a remote repository into a local branch.
Uploading local changes to a remote repository.
A situation where two branches of code have changes that cannot be automatically reconciled.
Application Programming Interface; a set of rules and protocols for building and interacting with software applications.
A boundary across which two independent systems meet and interact.
Graphical User Interface; a visual way of interacting with software using graphical elements.
Command Line Interface; a text-based way of interacting with software using command-line commands.
Integrated Development Environment; a software application that provides comprehensive facilities to computer programmers for software development.
A tool used to identify and remove errors or bugs from software code.
A program that translates code written in a high-level programming language into machine code.
A program that directly executes instructions written in a programming language without the need for prior compilation.
An error that occurs when code violates the rules of the programming language.
An error that occurs while a program is running, typically due to logical errors or unexpected conditions.
An error or unexpected condition that occurs during the execution of a program.
A programming technique where a function calls itself in its definition.
A control flow statement that allows code to be executed repeatedly based on a condition.
A data structure that stores a collection of elements, typically of the same type.
A data structure that stores a collection of elements in a specific order.
A data structure that stores an ordered collection of elements, which cannot be modified after creation.
A data structure that stores a collection of key-value pairs, allowing fast retrieval of values based on their keys.
A data structure that stores a collection of unique elements, without any particular order.
A data structure that follows the Last In, First Out (LIFO) principle, where elements are added and removed from the same end.
A data structure that follows the First In, First Out (FIFO) principle, where elements are added at the rear and removed from the front.
A specialized tree-based data structure that satisfies the heap property.
A tree data structure in which each node has at most two children.
A data structure consisting of a set of nodes and a set of edges that connect pairs of nodes.
The process of arranging elements in a specific order.
The process of finding a specific element within a collection of elements.
A mathematical notation that describes the limiting behavior of a function when the argument approaches a particular value or infinity.
The measure of how the runtime of an algorithm or function increases with the size of its input.
Relating to the behavior of a function as the input size approaches infinity.
The ability to accomplish a task with minimal wasted time, effort, or resources.
The process of making a system, design, or code as efficient as possible.
A software development methodology focused on iterative development, collaboration, and customer feedback.
A framework within the Agile methodology that emphasizes teamwork, accountability, and iterative progress.

A traditional linear software development methodology where progress flows steadily downwards through the phases of conception, initiation, analysis, design, construction, testing, deployment, and maintenance.
A method for managing knowledge work with an emphasis on just-in-time delivery while not overloading the team members.
A distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code during software development.
A web-based hosting service for version control using Git.
A web-based hosting service for projects that use either the Mercurial or Git revision control systems.
The practice of frequently integrating code changes into a shared repository, followed by an automated build and test process.
The practice of automatically deploying code changes to production environments after passing automated tests.
The process of encapsulating an application and its dependencies into a container that can run on any computing environment.
The process of creating a virtual representation of a physical computing device, such as a server, storage device, or network resource.
The delivery of computing services—including servers, storage, databases, networking, software, and analytics—over the internet.
An architectural style that structures an application as a collection of loosely coupled services, which are independently deployable and scalable.
Representational State Transfer; an architectural style for designing networked applications, emphasizing stateless communication and uniform resource interfaces.
JavaScript Object Notation; a lightweight data interchange format.
eXtensible Markup Language; a markup language that defines a set of rules for encoding documents in a format that is both human-readable and machine-readable.
Hypertext Transfer Protocol; the foundation of data communication for the World Wide Web.
Hypertext Transfer Protocol Secure; an extension of HTTP that provides secure communication over a computer network.
Transmission Control Protocol/Internet Protocol; the basic communication language or protocol of the internet.
Secure Sockets Layer; a standard security technology for establishing an encrypted link between a server and a client.
Secure Shell; a cryptographic network protocol for operating network services securely over an unsecured network.
Domain Name System; a hierarchical decentralized naming system for computers, services, or other resources connected to the internet or a private network.
Uniform Resource Locator; a reference to a web resource that specifies its location on a computer network and the mechanism for retrieving it.
Structured Query Language; a domain-specific language used in programming and designed for managing data held in a relational database management system.
Not Only SQL; a broad class of database management systems that differ from the classic relational database management system.
Object-Relational Mapping; a programming technique for converting data between incompatible type systems using object-oriented programming languages.
Create, Read, Update, Delete; a set of basic operations for persistent storage in a database or file system.
Model-View-Controller; a software design pattern for implementing user interfaces.
